chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Pneumococcal vaccines use purified capsular polysaccharide from several strains of Streptococcus pneumoniae to achieve active immunity.
    • The primary response occurs after the first administration of vaccine to a person without prior exposure to the antigen. A slow antibody response (predominantly immunoglobulin M) is produced.
    • The secondary response occurs when further administrations increase the antibody titre (predominantly immunoglobulin G).
    • Most adults will have had some previous exposure to S. pneumoniae, and so will develop a good immunoglobulin G antibody response to a single dose of pneumococcal vaccine by the third week following immunization.
    • Infants (children under 12 months), however, need a primary series of two injections to produce immunity.
  • There are two types of pneumococcal vaccine available in the UK:
    • Prevenar 13® is a 13-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV13) mainly suitable for children aged less than 2 years as part of the Childhood Immunization Programme, or for children aged less than 5 years considered to be at high risk of infection.
      • Conjugating the capsular polysaccharide to other proteins improves the immunogenicity of the vaccine in younger children.
      • Pneumococcal conjugate vaccines protect against pneumococcal meningitis, bacteraemia, pneumonia, and otitis media [Bernatoniene and Finn, 2005].
      • There is also evidence that pneumococcal conjugate vaccines provide 'herd immunity' by decreasing nasal carriage of S. pneumoniae, and reduce the incidence of penicillin-resistant pneumococci [Bernatoniene and Finn, 2005].
    • Pneumovax® is a 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPV23), suitable for older children (aged 2 years and over) and adults.
      • The 23 capsular types contained within the vaccine account for about 96% of the isolates that cause pneumococcal disease in the UK.
      • The overall effectiveness is difficult to estimate, but vaccination probably prevents about 50–70% of cases of pneumococcal bacteraemia.
      • The vaccine is probably ineffective at preventing non-bacteraemic pneumococcal pneumonia, otitis media, or exacerbations of chronic bronchitis.
      • There is no evidence for its effectiveness in children under 2 years of age.

[PHE, 2013a]
